name: grep
desc: grep is a common command-line tool used for searching for matching text content in files and outputting the results.

-a.name: Treat binary files as text files when searching.

-b.name: Prefix each line of output with the byte offset within the input file.

-c.name: Only output the count of matching lines.

-E.name: Use extended regular expressions for matching.

-F.name: Treat the search string as a fixed string, not a regular expression.

-G.name: Use basic regular expressions for matching.

-h.name: Suppress the file name prefix on output.

-l.name: Only output the names of files that contain at least one match.

-m.name: Stop reading the file after NUM matching lines.

-n.name: Prefix each line of output with the 1-based line number within its input file.

-q.name: Quiet mode, does not output any information.

-s.name: Silent mode, do not display error messages.

-v.name: Invert the sense of matching, to select non-matching lines.

content:
Example

  • grep 'hello' file.txt, search for lines containing hello in file.txt.
  • grep -r 'world' dir/, recursively search for lines containing world in dir/ directory and its subdirectories.
  • grep -n 'error' file.txt, search for lines containing error in file.txt and display line numbers.
  • grep -i 'apple' file.txt, search for lines containing apple in file.txt, ignoring case.
  • grep -E '[0-9]{3}' file.txt, search for lines containing three consecutive digits in file.txt.
